sentence: C all it the gift that keeps on giving.
Gift-card facilitatorBlackhawk Network Holdings ( HAWK ) was spun off from Safeway in April 2014, but it hasn't strayed far from its roots in the grocery-store channel.
The company still generates most of its revenue from gift cards sold at kiosks in grocery stores and other retail venues.
The number of grocery stores, convenience stores and other retail outlets that are part of Blackhawk's gift-card network has grown from 59,000 stores in 2010 to around 200,000 currently.
Safeway is still a big customer.
So are a number of other big grocery chains, such asKroger ( KR ), Giant Eagle and Publix, among others.
Those stores, or distribution partners, display gift cards on Gift Card Mall branded kiosks that Blackhawk operates, often near checkouts at the front of the store in previously unused space.
Grocery chains want them in their stores, says James Friedman, analyst with Susquehanna Financial Group.
"They don't take up much space, and they have a lot of dollar value per square foot," he said.
Whole Foods Market ( WFM ) has a pilot program with Blackhawk in about 50 stores, Patrick Cronin, Blackhawk's vice president of finance , told IBD.
Blackhawk sells and processes prepaid gift cards for 600 brands in 22 countries.

National brands in the U.S. includeStarbucks ( SBUX ),Home Depot ( HD ),Lowe's (LOW),Macy's (M),Nordstrom (JWN),Walt Disney (DIS),GameStop (GME) and Applebee's, among others, as well as various local merchants.
Cards get activated at cash registers via Blackhawk's network.
"Pretty much any time you buy a gift card at the vendor who is the provider of the gift card (such as at a Starbucks or Home Depot store), that is not Blackhawk," Friedman said.
"However, if you buy a Home Depot gift card at Safeway, that is Blackhawk."

Analysts say that one other U.S. company is also heavily involved in providing a network of gift cards at retail venues: the privately held InComm, which reportedly is exploring an initial public offering or outright sale.
Blackhawk gets a 3% commission on the face value of gift cards sold in its network.
Store distributors get 6%.
Blackhawk also sells and facilitates gift cards from card companies such asVisa (V),MasterCard (MA) andAmerican Express (AXP).
On those cards, Blackhawk splits a small fee with the store distributor.
"Almost all large merchants have a gift card program," Friedman says, so more of Blackhawk's growth is likely to come from consumers buying at grocery stores more frequently.

That is why store promotions for gift cards -- such as discounts on a customer's next grocery order or on gas purchases at the pump -- are said to be a key growth driver, even though promotions can vary from quarter to quarter.
"Consumers seem to have a big appetite for gift cards, and that appetite is growing," Friedman said.
Blackhawk's transaction count has grown over 20% a year since the first quarter of 2014, he says.
In this year's first quarter, it jumped 35% year-over-year.
Total operating revenue in the quarter grew 37% to $319.7 million.
Gift cards can also be purchased on Blackhawk's GiftCardMall.com website, including cards fromAmazon (AMZN),Staples (SPLS),eBay (EBAY),Outerwall 's (OUTR) Coinstar and others.
However, Blackhawk's e-commerce gift card business is small, accounting for only 3% of revenue, Cronin says.
"Their business model is dependent on the physical cards," said Gil Luria, analyst with Wedbush Securities.
"What makes them unique is that they have the space at grocery stores and the cash-register connections."
In the first quarter, the U.S. accounted for 62.5% of operating revenue, international 24.8% and corporate incentives and rewards 12.6%.
"They still have a lot of countries they can expand into," Luria said.
Blackhawk expects to launch in Poland, Indonesia and India over the next several quarters.
And it's negotiating a joint venture in China that would allow it to sell gift cards there by the end of this year.
The corporate incentives and rewards business has been growing rapidly on the back of a string of recent acquisitions, including Parago in late 2014.
In its Q1 2015 report, Blackhawk reported adjusted earnings of 34 cents per share vs. 10 cents a year earlier, for a 240% gain.
Excluding the impact of a tax benefit from the Safeway spinoff, EPS rose 143% to 17 cents.
As part of its spinoff from Safeway, Blackhawk gets $27 million a year in tax benefits for 15 years, or about 70 cents per share in extra earnings a year, Cronin says.
"It's darn good; we're excited" about the tax benefit, he said.
Not everyone is as excited about Blackhawk's business.

Since the company went public in 2013, quarterly earnings have been uneven and, with the exception of this year's first quarter, generally "disappointing," says analyst Luria, who is "neutral" on the stock.
Luria is also concerned that consumers' interest in physical gift cards will wane in favor of gift cards "through their mobile wallet applications."
Still, Luria said, "This shift to mobile in gift cards hasn't happened yet."
He noted that Blackhawk is still expanding its core business of "selling a physical manifestation of a digital good."
He added, "This year and next year, they will still grow at healthy rates based on existing business and acquisitions."
Cronin says that Blackhawk Network already has relationships with "big digital players" such asGoogle (GOOGL), Amazon and PayPal.
"Most don't have big gift card components on their wallet program," he said, adding, "Our goal is to provide them with gift cards through their wallets" should they want to expand gift-card programs.
Blackhawk, he notes, has built a "reference app" called GoWallet "to show big wallet players how gift cards might work within their wallet."
GoWallet allows people to load gift cards onto the app and check their balances.
It has 2 million registered users.
"We hope (that big digital wallet players) will build this technology into their own wallets so we can provide them gift cards.
We're hopeful," Cronin said.
